clean_content:
Definition / general

* Benign, likely reactive, gingival mass, clinically resembling a pyogenic granuloma and characterized histopathologically by a proliferation of mononuclear cells and multinucleated giant cells

Essential features

* Presents exclusively on the gingiva / alveolar ridge as a red, purple or blue nodular mass, clinically resembling a pyogenic granuloma* Considered reactive, frequently associated with trauma or local irritation* Often considered the soft tissue counterpart to the central giant cell granuloma, peripheral giant cell granuloma (PGCG) is comprised of a mesenchymal proliferation of mononuclear spindle shaped and polygonal cells with osteoclast type multinucleated giant cells interspersed with extravasated red blood cells and hemosiderin ([J Stomatol Oral Maxillofac Surg 2019;120:456](30677564))

Terminology

* Peripheral giant cell granuloma (PGCG) (most common terminology)* Giant cell epulis, peripheral giant cell epulis, peripheral giant cell reparative granuloma (uncommonly used)

ICD coding

* ICD-10
  + [K13.6](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/K00-K95/K00-K14/K13-/K13.6) - irritative hyperplasia of the oral mucosa+ [K06.8](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/K00-K95/K00-K14/K06-/K06.8) - other specified disorders of gingiva and edentulous alveolar ridge* ICD-11
    + [DA0D.Y](https://icd.who.int/browse/2025-01/mms/en#1903499403%2Fother) - other specified disorders of gingival or edentulous alveolar ridge

Epidemiology

* No strong age, sex or racial predilection
  + Mean age of ~37 years; highest prevalence in fourth and fifth decades ([J Oral Pathol Med 2018;47:454](29569293))+ Slight female predilection ([J Oral Pathol Med 2018;47:454](29569293))

Sites

* Exclusively on the gingiva
  + May arise on an edentulous alveolar ridge, near teeth or around implants ([Med Oral Patol Oral Cir Bucal 2019;24:e739](31655833))* Mandible is more common than the maxilla (3:2 ratio) ([J Oral Pathol Med 2018;47:454](29569293))* Most often anterior to the first molars ([Ann R Coll Surg Engl 2024;106:649](37365927))

Pathophysiology

N/A

Etiology

* Frequently associated with local irritants, such as previous / persistent trauma, calculus ([Ann R Coll Surg Engl 2024;106:649](37365927))* Lesions indistinguishable from peripheral giant cell granulomas have been associated with hyperparathyroidism ([Clin Case Rep 2023;11:e7823](37614292), [J Clin Med 2020;9:4042](33327593))
    + These lesions are better termed brown tumors of hyperparathyroidism

Diagrams / tables

N/A

Clinical features

* Red, blue, purple or variably pink mass of the gingiva / alveolar ridge* Variably ulcerated ([Ann R Coll Surg Engl 2024;106:649](37365927))* Sessile or pedunculated* Average size of 1.7 cm ([J Oral Pathol Med 2018;47:454](29569293))* May demonstrate cupping of the underlying bone

Diagnosis

* Diagnosis is made by histopathological examination

Laboratory

* Abnormal lab values are not associated with PGCG, although in rare instances, lesions indistinguishable from PGCG may be associated with hyperparathyroidism (abnormal serum parathyroid, calcium, phosphate levels) ([Clin Case Rep 2023;11:e7823](37614292), [J Clin Med 2020;9:4042](33327593))
  + These lesions are better termed brown tumors of hyperparathyroidism

Radiology description

* May demonstrate cupping resorption / erosion of the bone, although care should be taken to ensure that the lesion is not arising from within the bone as a central giant cell granuloma ([J Oral Pathol Med 2018;47:454](29569293))

Radiology images

Cannot find one - if whoever reviews has an image showing cupping of the bone in PGCG, that would be helpful!

Prognostic factors

* PCGCs are benign and demonstrate a good prognosis* Complete removal of the lesion down to periosteum with scaling of adjacent teeth to remove local irritants decreases likelihood of recurrence ([J Oral Pathol Med 2018;47:454](29569293))* Excision alone (without additional curettage) shows a ~16% recurrence rate ([J Oral Pathol Med 2018;47:454](29569293))

Case reports

* 29 year old woman with a peripheral giant cell granuloma of the maxillary gingiva ([J Dent Sci 2022;17:1434](35784156))* 38 year old man with a peripheral giant cell granuloma-like lesion as a first sign of hyperparathyroidism ([Clin Case Rep 2023;11:e7823](37614292))* 53 year old man with a peripheral giant cell granuloma associated with a dental implant ([BMC Oral Health 2019;19:283](31842866))

Treatment

* Excision, down to periosteum with bony curettage and removal of any potential irritants (e.g., calculus) ([Ann R Coll Surg Engl 2024;106:649](37365927))

Clinical images

Central giant cell granuloma:   
 swelling, extended to midline and excisional biopsy

Gross description

* Tan-brown mass, pedunculated or sessile* Prominent hemorrhage visible on cut surface

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Nodular proliferation of mesenchymal tissue surfaced by variably ulcerated squamous epithelium* Mesenchymal component contains an unencapsulated proliferation of mononuclear and multinucleated giant cells intermixed with abundant extravasated red blood cells and hemosiderin deposits ([Ann R Coll Surg Engl 2024;106:649](37365927))* Mitotic figures are frequently identified within the mononuclear cell population, although atypical mitotic figures should not be found* Reactive bone formation, similar to that seen in peripheral ossifying fibromas, may be seen

Sample pathology report

* Gingiva, excisional biopsy:
  + Peripheral giant cell granuloma (see comment)+ Comment: The microscopic sections show a proliferation of multinucleated giant cells surfaced by partially ulcerated squamous epithelium. The giant cell proliferation is set within a highly cellular and vascular background stroma containing ovoid mononuclear cells and zones of extravasated red blood cells. Because lesional tissue extends to the base of the specimen, clinical and radiographic correlation is advised to rule out a central component.

Differential diagnosis

* Clinical differential diagnosis for a vascular appearing nodule on the gingiva predominantly includes the entities below, all of which may be differentiated from a PGCG upon histopathological examination of the biopsy sample* Note: none of the entities below are predominated by a benign proliferation of multinucleated giant cells set within a highly vascular and cellular background stroma as is typical in PGCG
    + [Pyogenic granuloma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavitypyogenicgranuloma.html)
      - A common reactive lesion that may appear vascular and ulcerated but lacks multinucleated giant cells+ [Peripheral ossifying fibroma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityperipheralossifyingfibroma.html):
        - May occasionally demonstrate scattered multinucleated giant cells; however, the proliferation of giant cells does not predominate the bulk of the mesenchymal proliferation+ **Peripheral odontogenic cysts / tumors** (e.g., [peripheral odontogenic fibroma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillaodontogenicfibroma.html))
          - Typically lacks multinucleated giant cells and usually appears as firm, nonvascular gingival mass+ **Malignancy**:
            - While [squamous cell carcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityscc.html) may present as a vascular gingival mass, the gingiva is also a common site for metastatic lesions ([Head Neck Pathol 2019;13:103](30693455))* [Central giant cell granuloma (CGCG)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillacentralgiantcellgranuloma.html):
      + CGCGs are often considered the bony counterpart to PGCGs, thus the histopathological features are often indistinguishable, although PGCGs often are surfaced by squamous epithelium whereas CGCGs are often fragmented pieces of mesenchymal tissue+ Additionally, crevicular epithelium may be seen at the base of the specimen in a PGCG and would be absent in a CGCG+ If lesional tissue extends to the base of the specimen or if surface epithelium cannot be identified, clinical and radiographic correlation is vital in determining the difference in CGCG versus PGCG
